s.text: The D1S425-D1S2827 'window' yielded a PDT global P value of 0.032.

The D1S425-D1S2827 two-marker haplotype window in the 1q32 region showed evidence for transmission disequilibrium via the global PDT, while no other windows showed evidence of association using this multiallelic test.
Every two- or three-marker 'window' was examined by moving the window across the 1q32-42 region one marker at a time from centromere to telomere.
A dyad is informative only when the offspring has a heterozygous genotype different from that of the parent, thus avoiding the bias of using inferred phase assignments [ 18, 19].
Thus, the evidence for linkage at 1q41 is reproducible in independent collections using the identical markers.
The genotype data from the 11 microsatellites used in the study were analyzed using PEDCHECK and RELATIVE to identify errors in Mendelian inheritance and to confirm familial relationships [ S2, S3].

This program outputs separate results for the TDT, S-TDT and the combined TDT/S-TDT (referred to herein as C-TDT).

Poly ADP ribosyl polymerase (PARP; also referred to as ADPRT [adenosine diphosphate ribosyltransferase]) was initially suggested as the relevant candidate gene in the region [ 11, 12], but that finding was not reproduced in other family collections [ 13].
Maximum-likelihood haplotypes were generated using GENEHUNTER PLUS for the 274 families with at least one typed parent.
With the addition of five new fine-map markers and 24 new families, the best evidence for linkage was slightly reduced (LOD = 1.23) and shifted telomeric to marker D1S2616 (Fig.
Twenty-four additional families were included beyond the families that comprised the original Minnesota Cohorts 1 and 2 [ S13, S14].

The evidence for linkage was examined in the subset of families that carried the 'risk' haplotypes, defined as those families carrying three-marker haplotypes from D1S229 to D1S2641 that displayed at least a 2:1 transmission:non-transmission ratio (see Fig.
The data reported here confirm the evidence for genetic linkage at 1q41 in 210 SLE sibpair families from the Minnesota collection.
Twenty-four additional families were included beyond the families that comprised the original Minnesota Cohorts 1 and 2 [ S13, S14].
When only white families were considered, the peak multipoint LOD score remained at marker D1S2616 (LOD = 0.99; Fig.

Furthermore, we report new evidence for transmission disequilibrium of both single marker alleles and short marker haplotypes from the 1q41-42 interval in 122 trio families and in the total dataset of 332 SLE families.

Fine-mapping in the 1q41 region by Moser et al [ 14] also showed that the highest overall LOD score in 127 families of the Oklahoma collection was at D1S229, and the greatest degree of allele sharing in 78 white families was at D1S2616.
One hundred and twenty-two trio families were also collected.

The GENEHUNTER PLUS haplotype output was used to identify families with founders carrying the seven three-marker haplotypes in the 1q41 region (D1S229-D1S2641) that had a TDT transmission:nontransmission ratio of at least 2:1 (66% transmission rate).

Furthermore, we report new evidence for transmission disequilibrium of both single marker alleles and short marker haplotypes from the 1q41-42 interval in 122 trio families and in the total dataset of 332 SLE families.

Poly ADP ribosyl polymerase (PARP; also referred to as ADPRT [adenosine diphosphate ribosyltransferase]) was initially suggested as the relevant candidate gene in the region [ 11, 12], but that finding was not reproduced in other family collections [ 13].
A dyad is informative only when the offspring has a heterozygous genotype different from that of the parent, thus avoiding the bias of using inferred phase assignments [ 18, 19].

These haplotype results should be viewed with some caution, since they are uncorrected for the multiple allele combinations tested, and the possibility of Type I errors may be increased.
This study was approved by the Human Subjects Review Board at the Mayo Clinic and at the University of Minnesota.
